description: Old English trenket (“a sort of knife”), hence, probably, a toy knife worn as an ornament; probably from an Old French dialectal form of trenchier (“to cut”). Compare trench.

entries.meaning: A small showy ornament or piece of jewelry
examples: That little trinket around her neck must have cost a bundle.

entries.meaning: A thing of little value; a trifle; a toy.
examples: It's only a little trinket, but it reminds her of him.

entries.meaning: (nautical) A three-cornered sail formerly carried on a ship's foremast, probably on a lateen yard.
examples: Sayling alwayes with the sheates of mainesaile and trinket warily in our hands.

verbs.description: trinket (third-person singular simple present trinkets, present participle trinketing, simple past and past participle trinketed)

entries.meaning: (obsolete) To give trinkets; to court favour.
